metadata.titel_preek: Easter Season Cycle: John 20 and Job 38-42

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God invades the realm of Death and human despair (Night) to rescue humanity from the grave and create faith through His self-revelation.

tekstueel_bewijs: He arose from the kingdom of Death and carried away its spoils.
The living Son of God had appeared to him personally.
God has entered our pain and been wounded by it... yet has been raised triumphant.

object.identificatie: The life of humanity / Redemption from the 'Night'
tekstueel_bewijs: receive the gift of eternal light and life in his name
grant his divine life to all who come to him

zender.identificatie: God the Father / The Living Word
tekstueel_bewijs: The Bible sets before us a baffling, even an infuriating God who is really God

ontvanger.identificatie: Mary, Thomas, Job, and the Hearer (Humanity)
tekstueel_bewijs: to you and to me: 'Blessed are they who do not see and yet believe'
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer is the Receiver of a revelation they cannot produce.

helper.identificatie: The Holy Spirit / The Proclaimed Word
tekstueel_bewijs: Through the Word of God the Holy Spirit creates such faith
helper.rol_van_god: God is both Subject (the actor) and Helper (the Spirit creating faith).
helper.rol_van_geest: External power that creates internal competence (faith).

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin, Death, Satan, and the 'Night' of human limitation.
tekstueel_bewijs: the night in which Sin and Death reign
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not a moral failing but an ontological and cosmic reality (Death/Satan) that humans are powerless to overcome.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human response of faith and confession following the encounter with the Risen Lord.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer (Mary, Thomas, Job)
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The human response (Program 2) is strictly a result of God's prior action (Program 1). Faith is 'created' by the Word, not generated by the Subject.

voorbeelden_god_subject: He arose from the kingdom of Death.
The Lord looks straight through Thomas... to you and to me.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: Mary Magdalene came to the tomb.
We can choose a god who suits us.

voorbeelden: faith must stand... in the place of ambiguity
Job’s great longing is for revelation.
they did not know the scripture
having power to grant his divine life
the few shreds of solace that we are able to snatch

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on the 'Pouvoir' (Power) of God in the face of human 'Non-pouvoir' (Inability). Grace is presented as God's sovereign ability to act where man is paralyzed by death.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: The narrative moves from S2 (Night/Death) through ~S2 (Mary's futile visit/Joseph's spices) to the sudden intrusion of S1 (Resurrection) which resolves ~S1 (Doubt).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Resolution is achieved not by human effort but by the 'Voice out of the Whirlwind'—a divine intrusion.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Extremely high; S2 is described as 'merciless' and 'irrevocable'.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. It consistently places God as the active Subject of salvation and treats human faith as a gift/result of revelation rather than a prerequisite or a work.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: If we don’t like the tornadoes... we can absolve our man-made gods.

indicatoren_genade.indicator: God as Subject of active verbs
indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: He arose from the kingdom of Death and carried away its spoils.
The reign of Death is stark, merciless, irrevocable.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Biblical figures are used as 'types' of human helplessness and receivers of grace, not as moral examples to emulate.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides a theocentric reading: God reveals Himself to Thomas/Job.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and awe; the burden of 'producing' faith or 'overcoming' death is removed.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The three sections (Mary, Thomas, Job) are perfectly integrated into a single narrative of God's intrusion into human 'Night'.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: He arose from the kingdom of Death and carried away its spoils.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit creates the faith that the human Subject lacks.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin is linked to Death and Night—a state of being rather than just a list of misdeeds.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God as the primary Actant. The 'Night' is a formidable Opponent, making the 'Light' a true act of Grace.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain as is; this is appropriate for Easter.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: Soteriology (God's act) correctly precedes and enables the Secondary Program (Human faith).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This is a masterclass in grace-oriented preaching. It avoids the trap of turning Thomas or Job into 'heroes of faith' and instead presents them as trophies of God's relentless pursuit.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'Night' metaphor, Greimas shows that 'Night' functions as a cosmic Opponent that necessitates a Subject-switch from Man to God.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the Greek of John 20; semiotics reveals that the sermon's 'engine' is driven by God's 'Pouvoir-faire'.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas reveals that the sermon's power comes from the 'Non-pouvoir' of the human actants, which creates the narrative 'lack' only God can fill.

appendices.notities: The sermon consistently avoids 'If/Then' legalism, opting for 'Because/Therefore' gospel logic.
